results.title: In Talks on Ukraine, U.S. and Russia Deadlock Over NATO Expansion
results.abstract: Both sides expressed some optimism after negotiations in Geneva, but did not break an impasse over Russia’s demand that Ukraine never become a member of NATO.
results.byline: By Anton Troianovski and David E. Sanger

multimedia.caption: The American delegation, left, and its Russian counterparts as they met in Geneva on Monday.

results.title: North Korea Launches 2nd Ballistic Missile in a Week, South Korea Says
results.abstract: The launch came as the U.N. Security Council met to discuss the country’s growing weapons threat. The U.S. said the latest test “highlights the destabilizing impact” of the North’s weapons program.

multimedia.caption: A television at a Seoul railroad station on Tuesday showed file footage of a North Korean missile test.

results.title: Can the West Stop Russia From Invading Ukraine?
results.abstract: The United States, its NATO allies and Russia meet this week in a whirlwind of diplomacy aimed at averting the largest military action in Europe since World War II. Here’s a guide to what’s at stake.

multimedia.caption: A Ukrainian soldier patrolling the front lines in Avdiivka, Ukraine, on Dec. 2. Tensions between Ukraine and Russia have been simmering since 2014.
multimedia.copyright: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times

results.title: Source of Mysterious Gas Leak Explosion in Canadian Town Stumps Officials
results.abstract: An explosion last summer in an Ontario community built on 19th-century gas wells has left locals searching for answers and some certainty that their town will ever recover.

multimedia.caption: Downtown Wheatley, Ontario, where a large gas explosion last August destroyed three buildings.
multimedia.copyright: Tara Walton for The New York Times

results.title: Haitian Prime Minister Had Close Links With Murder Suspect
results.abstract: New evidence suggests the man who took over from Haiti’s murdered president had close links to a prime suspect in the assassination — and that the two stayed in contact even after the crime.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: President Jovenel Moïse, who was assassinated in July, led Haiti by decree and turned to authoritarian tactics.
multimedia.copyright: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times

results.title: How the ‘Djokovic Affair’ Came Back to Bite Australia’s Prime Minister
results.abstract: Scott Morrison thought he had a political winner. Now, with an election looming, Australians debate their government’s fairness and competence.

multimedia.caption: Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia used the news about Novak Djokovic’s visa to return to a well-tested tactic: stirring voter support with appeals to tough border enforcement.

results.title: Revolt in Kazakhstan: What’s Happening, and Why It Matters
results.abstract: As protests in the oil-rich Central Asian country gain momentum, the events threaten to reverberate across the region.

multimedia.caption: Riot police during a protest on Wednesday over an increase in energy prices in Almaty, Kazakhstan.

results.title: Freelance Reporter for The New York Times Is Put on Trial in Zimbabwe
results.abstract: The reporter, Jeffrey Moyo, has been accused of helping two Times journalists enter Zimbabwe from South Africa using bogus credentials, a charge that even the government admits is on ‘shaky ground.’

multimedia.caption: Jeffrey Moyo, a freelance reporter for The New York Times, is scheduled to go on trial on Wednesday.

results.title: David Sassoli, President of the European Parliament, Dies at 65
results.abstract: He was a well-known journalist in his native Italy before going into politics, and devoted his tenure to making the Parliament more prominent.
results.byline: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk

multimedia.caption: David Sassoli, president of the European Parliament, during the opening of a plenary session in Strasbourg, France, last year.

results.title: Russia Positioning Helicopters, in Possible Sign of Ukraine Plans
results.abstract: The step, which could be an indication that planning for an attack continues, comes as the number of Russian troops at the border has remained steady in recent weeks, despite U.S. expectations of a surge.
results.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Michael Crowley and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: Russian troops near Ukraine in December. U.S. officials say Moscow’s window for an invasion is limited.

results.title: Dorms Pop Up in Spain as More Students Seek Housing Away From Home
results.abstract: The country’s student population has become increasingly mobile, fueling investments in accommodations, largely funded by foreign capital.

multimedia.caption: Brian Dervishi, an Italian student, in a studio he rents in the Livensa Living student dorm in Málaga, Spain.
multimedia.copyright: Laura Leon for The New York Times

results.title: Russian Troops Will Stay to Finish Job in Kazakhstan, Putin Says
results.abstract: Blaming “internal and external forces” for the unrest in the resource-rich Central Asian country, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia set no deadline for the withdrawal of the forces his country sent there.

multimedia.caption: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia joined a meeting of the Collective Security Treaty Organization, a body akin to NATO, via video conference on Monday.

results.title: Uganda Reopens Schools After World’s Longest Covid Shutdown
results.abstract: Many countries have closed classrooms on and off, but Uganda had kept more than 10 million students at home since March 2020. Critics say it took a heavy toll.
results.byline: By Musinguzi Blanshe and Abdi Latif Dahir

multimedia.caption: Children back in class at Kitante Primary School in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday.
multimedia.copyright: Esther Ruth Mbabazi for The New York Times

results.title: Magawa, Rat That Hunted Land Mines, Dies in Retirement
results.abstract: The African giant pouched rat sniffed out more than 100 mines and other pieces of unexploded ordnance in Cambodia over five years, winning hearts and an international award.

multimedia.caption: Magawa with his handler last year in Siem Reap, Cambodia.

results.title: San Francisco Ballet Appoints Tamara Rojo to Artistic Director
results.abstract: Rojo, who has given the English National Ballet a new allure, succeeds Helgi Tomasson as just the fourth director to lead the San Francisco company.

multimedia.caption: Tamara Rojo will succeed Helgi Tomasson as the artistic director of San Francisco Ballet.
multimedia.copyright: Kalpesh Lathigra for The New York Times

results.title: Kazakhstan Says Russian Troops Will Start Leaving This Week
results.abstract: The military response to recent unrest appears to be a win for President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his Kazakh counterpart, Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, who solidified his grip at a time when it was most shaky.
results.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Ivan Nechepurenko

multimedia.caption: A building that was torched during recent unrest in Almaty, Kazakhstan, on Tuesday.

results.title: Suspect in South Africa’s Parliament Fire Is Sent for Psychiatric Check
results.abstract: If the man is found fit to stand trial, he will faces charges that now include terrorism. His lawyers said he would protest with a hunger strike.

multimedia.caption: Zandile Christmas Mafe, who is suspected of setting the fires that tore through South Africa’s parliamentary complex, appeared in court in Cape Town on Tuesday.

results.title: A Growing Gap
results.abstract: We look at Omicron’s toll in New York and Seattle, two cities with timely data.
results.byline: By David Leonhardt and Ashley Wu

multimedia.caption: Covid testing in Brooklyn.
multimedia.copyright: Anna Watts for The New York Times

results.title: In Southern Africa, Success Against H.I.V. Offers Hope for Beating Back Another Virus
results.abstract: A former Africa correspondent, who covered the height of the AIDS epidemic there 15 years ago, finds lessons in the remarkable progress against that virus for our current fight.

multimedia.caption: A near-empty ward of the Chongwe District Hospital outside Lusaka, Zambia. Fifteen years ago, a hospital like this would have been overflowing with H.I.V. patients lying two or three to a bed.

results.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
results.abstract: A groundbreaking medical procedure.

multimedia.caption: Surgeons performed an eight-hour transplant of a genetically modified pig’s heart at the University of Maryland School of Medicine on Friday.
multimedia.copyright: University of Maryland School of Medicine

results.title: U.N. Seeks Huge Aid Increase to Prevent ‘Catastrophe’ in Afghanistan
results.abstract: The $5 billion appeal comes as a severe drought and the toll of decades of war have plunged three-quarters of the country’s population into acute poverty, according to the United Nations.

multimedia.caption: A child suffering from severe malnutrition at the Indira Gandhi Children’s Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan, in October.
multimedia.copyright: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times

results.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Russia Plays Down Invasion Threat
results.abstract: The U.S. called some demands “non-starters.”

multimedia.caption: U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Wendy Sherman, left, and Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov attended security talks at the United States Mission in Geneva, Switzerland on Monday.

results.title: Nearly 5 Years After Grenfell Fire, U.K. Tells Developers to Pay for Upgrades
results.abstract: After a deadly high-rise blaze in 2017, countless instances of unsafe building practices came to light. The latest plan to address them expands who will be covered.

multimedia.caption: Grenfell Tower, a high-rise residential building in London, now stands covered in what the government calls a “protective wrapping.”

results.title: Famed White Cliffs of Sicily Are Defaced in an Act of Vandalism
results.abstract: Vandals stained a cliff formation known as the Staircase of the Turks with red splotches over the weekend. Residents of a nearby town banded together for a successful cleanup.

multimedia.caption: The Scala dei Turchi in Realmonte, Italy, on Saturday, before the cleanup.

results.title: Crashed Pilot Is Pulled to Safety Seconds Before Train Plows Through
results.abstract: Los Angeles police officers pulled the pilot of a small plane away from the tracks moments before a train smashed into it at high speed.
results.byline: By Daniel Victor and Claire Fahy

multimedia.caption: A still from bodycam footage shows a crashed plane moments before a train hit the wreckage in Los Angeles on Sunday.

results.title: In India, mask wearing is down, even as case numbers rise.
results.abstract: Health officials are finding it harder to impose regulations despite signs that Omicron is beginning to take hold.

multimedia.caption: Police officers dispersing beachgoers in Mumbai on Sunday to enforce Covid restrictions.

results.title: Breakouts and lockdowns in Chinese cities make a risk-free Olympics look unlikely.
results.abstract: Officials are racing to extinguish a spate of coronavirus infections around the country.

multimedia.caption: Members of a disinfection team at the press center for the Beijing 2022 Winter Olympics on Monday.

results.title: Pundit Accountability
results.abstract: Writers and experts should be transparent about what they got wrong.

multimedia.caption: Covid testing in Houston.

results.title: In U.S.-Russia Talks, How Far Can Putin Turn Back the Clock?
results.abstract: The Cold War echoes of the negotiations unfolding this week in a series of meetings between Russia and the West are a reminder that there is nothing permanent about Europe’s security arrangements.

multimedia.caption: Russian tactical combat exercises in the Rostov region, east of Ukraine, in December.

results.title: The Biden administration gave a preview of how it would punish Russia if it invaded Ukraine.
results.abstract: Such moves are rarely telegraphed in advance, but advisers say they are hoping to influence the decisions of Russia’s leader, Vladimir V. Putin.
results.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

multimedia.caption: Russian troops during military exercises in December.

results.title: U.S. and Russia Will Discuss European Security, but Without Europeans
results.abstract: The coming talks in Geneva are bilateral, reviving old fears that the two Cold War powers will forge a deal on their own.

multimedia.caption: Ukrainian reservists taking part in a military exercise last month near Kyiv, Ukraine.

results.title: As Its Population Soars to 40, Rum Isle Glimpses a Future in the Mist
results.abstract: With four new families recently arriving, the remote and rainy island in the Hebrides is experiencing its version of a population surge, although residents new and old concede living here isn’t easy.

multimedia.caption: Approaching the Isle of Rum on a misty day in December.

results.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Gets 4 Years for Greeting a Crowd and Having Walkie-Talkies
results.abstract: Myanmar’s ousted civilian leader was convicted on three more counts under Covid and telecommunications rules, which her defenders said were politically motivated.
des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

multimedia.caption: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2015. She was sentenced in Myanmar on Monday to four years in prison for possessing walkie-talkies in her home and for violating Covid-19 protocols.

results.title: Your Monday Briefing
results.abstract: Key diplomatic talks about Ukraine.

multimedia.caption: The Russian deputy foreign minister, Sergei A. Ryabkov, in June. He will meet with U.S. negotiators in talks aimed at de-escalating tensions on Ukraine.
